Duo_Maxwell

ultimtely, the sancitity and value of marriage depends upon it's members, not society, not government, no one except the the two people who voluntarily enter into it. One person's belief in a sanctity of marriage applies to their marriage, not your's or anyone else's. True, many, if not the majority of people in marriages do not find a value or sancitity, but that does not mean it has none for all. True, many people do find value or sanctity, but that does not mean it has any for all. The sancitity and value of marriage is a case by case subject that cannot rationally apply to everyone. Therefore, any argument that applies a few to the whole is not valid.

You're thinking is right on, sinjin.
 
 Although it's kinda hush-hush, it has been determined (especially in the more charismatic churches) that when one "goes further" in religion the other feels alienated and problems/troubles that probably would have never risen in their relationship oozes out. A new circle of friends emerge which make the one that is "left behind" feel closed out and closed off. Arguments then seem to erupt daily and most of it over who is doing the "right thing" according to that religion, followed all too often by divorce.

 
 Can we go a little bit further and clarify that often, the "troubles" that arise have little to do with the actual couple's relationship, but rather are the result of the undue interference that is exerted by the church and new "friends".
 
 When it comes to the "sanctity of marriage", I accept that the church is the qualified source for making judgements on what is holy. However, many gay couples are simply seeking the legal right to marry. In such cases, the church can keep it's sanctity where it belongs.

 Didn't say it would! It is meant to remind gays and lesbians that we have, and will fight back. The Stonewall riots were the first time that gays fought back against oppression. It started with a bunch of drag queens throwing bricks at the police. It was a way of saying we will not take this any longer. It is the picture of that that gays should remember today! It reminds us that will fought then and we will fight now, until we are no longer harrassed or denied rights based on perceived or real sexual orientation. I remind people again...gay right are not just for gays. They are for everyone. It is not about your real sexual orientation, it is what people percieve is your sexual orientation. 80% of those gay bashed are straight. Somebody thought they were gay. People who are fired from their jobs for being gay may in fact have been straight, someone thought they were gay!

From the Christian point of view: (based on the teachings of the Bible)
 
 Adultery = wrong
 
 Divorce = wrong
 
 homosexual sex = wrong
 
 sex outside of marriage = wrong
 
 stealing = wrong
 
 murder = wrong
 
 The list could go on and on. To those of you that talked about the "Christians" that have failed to uphold some of these above mentioned things as wrong: (adultery and divorce) 
 Don't let the hypocrisy of a few taint your judgment of all Christians. All of those things are wrong (according to the Bible) but there isn't a point value that God puts on them. Homosexuals aren't any worse than anyone else who sins, that is the point that many Christians forget. In God's eyes, sin is sin is sin.

One question I would like to get answered is should the US have an amendment against adultery? I think this dose a lot more harm to the "sanctity and value of marriage"
 
 Just had to put in my $.02, and would you all let me know if there is ever a good answer?

 
 Nobody I know sanctions adultery. There are already serious consequences built in against it. As far a same sex marriage, I know of nobody that is suggesting legal penalties for it unless one considers the refusal to legally recognize it a legal penalty. Certainly nobody has been jailed or fined for attempting such marriages. Privately performed ceremonies as such are not punished.
